column4: hi guys i seem to have a broken external usb hardrive - been trying to format it/repartition it in ubuntu but it's not working - can anyone help me out. used qtparted to create new partition etc a few times and when remounted it comes up not full capacity and with a folder on it called lost+found - which was a folder that used to be on it before reformatting!
lost+found is always added to an empty directory when you create a new file system.
that's not an error, that's normal behavior
really?
yes. on an ext2 or ext3 file system, always
ah weird, it's only a usb drive, i wanted to just completely blank it so i can back stuff up, it seems to have a few gig used up on nothing and this folder?
the thing about not using webmin is political, and I wish people would stop confusing political with technical
nothing in that folder is of course normal.  it's for placing recovered files after an fsck
i didn't realise that, i figured if it's an external backup drive it'd have nothing on there
also, a few gigs are always used up by file system overhead
you can erase the lost+found directory but it won't buy you anything
- so am i best using ext3? i was told that fat32 couldn't support the full 160gb on linux over usb
the file system overhead is also normal.  It sounds, actually, as if you don't have a problem.
you should never use fat unless you need to read/write from both linux and windows
i don't need to use the drive with windows, but is it ok in 1 partition on ext3? cos on fat someone said it would have to be in two partition
you mean because of the size?  the biggest I've done with ext3 is 120, but I don't know of a limitation like that.
I would have to check.  in any event, definitely _don't_ use FAT, it has no permissions and is missing other important file system features.
yeah the size - is there anyway i can check the limit or could you for me?
let me take a look at the docs
i don't wanna back stuff up and then get screwd over by it corrupting or something and it's not convenient in two partitions
thanks a lot = you've been loads of help, appreciated
as Kingsqueak said, the limit is way higher than 160 gig
